videos.title: Oddworld x Souly - wzf / maybach (2024)
videos.description: The music video for "WZF / Maybach" by Oddworld x Souly is a visually striking and dynamic production. The video features high-energy performances and a mix of urban and futuristic aesthetics. With vibrant colors and fast-paced edits, the visual storytelling complements the rhythm and intensity of the track. The artists are showcased in various locations, including industrial backdrops and sleek, modern settings, adding to the video's edgy and stylish vibe. The direction creatively blends elements of hip-hop culture with innovative visual effects, making it a captivating watch from start to finish.

videos.title: Ken Carson - Fighting My Demons (2023)
videos.description: The music video for "Fighting My Demons" by Ken Carson, directed by Cole Bennett, was released in 2023 and features unique, glitchy visuals. The video presents a series of grainy, 3D footage that gives off the impression of being shot with night-vision goggles, offering a surreal viewing experience. It mainly showcases Ken Carson partying and performing his lyrics, creating a montage that aligns with the song's themes. The video's eerie and dark aesthetics were noted for drawing inspiration from the style of 1990s Japanese cinema, culminating in a profound, existential moment where Ken faces a haunting black void, adding depth and narrative to the visual experience.

videos.alt_text: adidas - Your Future Is Not Mine
videos.title: adidas - Your Future Is Not Mine (2016)
videos.description: The 2016 Adidas commercial "Your Future is Not Mine," directed by Terence Neale, features influential creatives like Aleali May, Luka Sabbat, and Iman Shumpert, among others, who march confidently towards an optimistic future, challenging the preconceived notions of a dystopian tomorrow. This campaign, produced by the advertising agency Johannes Leonardo, emphasizes individual empowerment and the message that one's future is theirs to create, rallying viewers to defy negative expectations and shape their own destinies through creativity and personal initiative.

videos.title: Shit Robot "Take 'Em Up" (2010)
videos.description: The music video for "Take 'Em Up" by Shit Robot, featuring Nancy Whang, merges retro and modern visuals to create a vibrant, psychedelic effect. Set against an electro-disco track, the video shows characters in colorful 80s outfits moving through surreal cityscapes with playful animations and dynamic edits, enhancing the song's upbeat rhythm. Rotoscoping by Magdelena Turnier, Jairo Neto, Camilo Rosas, Brett Bittner, Atsushi Yamamoto, Eoin Whelehan and Chris Mooney. Contributed by Till Brokhausen.

videos.title: Flume feat. MAY-A - Say Nothing (2022)
videos.description: The music video for "Say Nothing" by Flume featuring MAY-A, directed by Michael Hili, offers a visually captivating and surreal experience. It includes psychedelic visuals, with Flume donning a bleach-blonde hairstyle and posing on motorcycles, while MAY-A is seen submerged in black sand. The video uses stark contrasts and vibrant colors to complement the song's themes of post-relationship clarity and emotional expression. This trippy and avant-garde style enhances the song's narrative, making it a standout piece in Flume's discography.

videos.description: The 2016 Adidas commercial "Your Future is Not Mine," directed by Terence Neale, features influential creatives like Aleali May, Luka Sabbat, and Iman Shumpert, among others, who march confidently towards an optimistic future, challenging the preconceived notions of a dystopian tomorrow. This campaign, produced by the advertising agency Johannes Leonardo, emphasizes individual empowerment and the message that one's future is theirs to create, rallying viewers to defy negative expectations and shape their own destinies through creativity and personal initiative.

videos.alt_text: Chinese Man - Too Late feat. Stogie T, KT Gorique & FP
videos.title: Chinese Man - Too Late feat. Stogie T, KT Gorique & FP (2024)
videos.description: Victor Haegelin, a Paris-based stop-motion artist known as "Patator," crafted a remarkable music video for "Too Late" by the French trip-hop ensemble Chinese Man, showcasing a mix of stop-motion artistry and fourth-wall-breaking moments within a creative workshop setting. The video uniquely interprets the song's theme of life's fleeting nature through a storytelling horse on a metaphorical hamster wheel, highlighted by its captivating grin, DJing prowess, and breakdancing moves.

A cinematic reflection on youth, ambition, and the bittersweet passage of time. Directed by Loris Russier, with stunning cinematography by Edouard Le Grelle and rich, moody color grading by Jacob McKee, the video immerses viewers in a visually striking journey through late-night cityscapes, fleeting romance, and moments of introspection. Blending elegance with raw emotion, "Twenties" captures the highs and lows of coming of age, wrapped in GIVĒON’s signature soulful sound. videos.title: Victoria Monet - Alright (2024)
videos.description: The music video for "Alright" by Victoria Monét, directed by Dave Meyers, is a vibrant homage to Janet Jackson, featuring high-energy choreography and striking visuals. In the video, Monét channels Jackson's iconic style, wearing a black-and-white fedora and suit, and performing dynamic dance routines reminiscent of Jackson's 1990s and 2000s era. The video, choreographed by Sean Bankhead, showcases Monét's impressive dance skills and captures the essence of liberation and celebration. Made in collaboration with Jacobi Mehringer, Anna Arnell, and Mia Barnes.

videos.title: Ken Carson - Fighting My Demons (2023)
videos.description: The music video for "Fighting My Demons" by Ken Carson, directed by Cole Bennett, was released in 2023 and features unique, glitchy visuals. The video presents a series of grainy, 3D footage that gives off the impression of being shot with night-vision goggles, offering a surreal viewing experience. It mainly showcases Ken Carson partying and performing his lyrics, creating a montage that aligns with the song's themes. The video's eerie and dark aesthetics were noted for drawing inspiration from the style of 1990s Japanese cinema, culminating in a profound, existential moment where Ken faces a haunting black void, adding depth and narrative to the visual experience.

The video's eerie and dark aesthetics were noted for drawing inspiration from the style of 1990s Japanese cinema, culminating in a profound, existential moment where Ken faces a haunting black void, adding depth and narrative to the visual experience.
